subject: Re: [junit] Testability
msgSnippet: ... I admit, this is all I was really thinking about at the time.  I had Robert Martin s recent book on my mind, specifically the TDD bowling game application
messageBody:
--- Steven Taschuk <staschuk@...> wrote:
> I gather from your comments that you consider it an
> important principle of object-oriented development
> that a one-to-one (or nearly one-to-one)
> correspondence between the objects being modelled
> and the code objects used to model them is
> desirable.

I admit, this is all I was really thinking about at
the time. I had Robert Martin's recent book on my
mind, specifically the TDD bowling game application
(chapter 6). Immediately afterward, as I mulled over
what I'd said and talked about it with others, I
remembered how commonly objects in OOP are pretty lame
representations of anything real.

For example, JavaBeans are nothing but simple data
structures with inheritance. The ubiquitous
"services" in today's many service oriented
architectures (e.g., JMX-based J2EE servers like JBoss
& JRun 4) are fundamentally JavaBeans with lifecycle
management. Other poor examples of objects modeling
reality are Hashtable, LinkedList, and certainly
Object!

> I have a feeling (entirely unsupported by any
> knowledge of the history of the field) that this
> principle might have arisen in the context of the
> analysis and design of simulations, rather than
> more general software development. It belongs to
> simulations, imho, and is not very useful elsewhere.

I'm not very knowledgeable about the historical
details either, but now am more interested.
Nevertheless, I think the correspondence principle is
helpful in data modeling, like for designing databases
(e.g., Person, Employee, Group, and Address tables).
It's also helpful for UI programming with its windows,
buttons, menus, etc.

But on the other hand, of the least important things
in XP and TDD is what you name the objects and methods
initially (you always can and should refactor the
names to be communicative, but initially it's not as
important as getting the outputs right). It's amazing
how much a very clean, tight TDD design, at the end,
can look so different from what one would have
developed if going with the top-down, modeling objects
approach.

[...]
> Processes do not represent any real-world object;
> they are entirely constructs of the model. The
> question of faithfulness of representation doesn't
> arise.

I am a little on the fence with this example. You can
explain that a process has a start and an end, ways of
interacting with the environment, that they use
resources, and are controlled, enabled or regulated by
a larger system. In this sense, a software process
could correspond to a natural process, like
photosynthesis or blood clotting.

> Resources often do represent real-world objects, but
> it is highly desirable that the representations have
> properties those objects do not -- sharability among
> concurrently executing processes, for example.

How do you represent "shareability" as a property in
something like a software file? Is it that different
(correspondence-wise) from making photocopies of a
file and letting several people read them at the same
time? I don't know. "Shareability" is another one of
these "-ability" words that seem difficult to explain
because they are really (I think) vague terms for more
precise things we have yet to analyze.

> This illustrates a mode completely different from
> that of simulation, one in which the greatest good
> of the model is convenience for its clients (be they

> software or human), and faithfulness of
> representation is, if not meaningless, of
> marginal, zero, or even negative utility. In such
> modes, adding behaviour to improve testability does
> not necessarily corrupt the design. (Refactoring
> might be better, but adding might do.)

[...]
> Changeability is imho the most desirable property of
> code, and beats faithfulness of representation any
> day.

I wonder if "changeability" could be reduced and made
more precise by analysis, like I am trying to reduce
"testability" and "maintainability." I think most of
these "-ability" words are shorthand for more
fundamental principles that, if made explicit, would
help raise software engineering to a more sophisticated
art form if not a science.

Scott Stirling
